Award.AwardTitle: TURBO: The Undergraduate Saco River Biodiversity Observatory -- A Long-Term Ecological Research-Style Research Experience to Enhance STEM Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
STEM education is increasingly important for success in a society that depends on science and technology, but college students' persistence in STEM programs of study, which are often dominated by traditional lectures and standard lab exercises, is generally low. Integrating undergraduate research opportunities into the curriculum has been shown to increase student learning and persistence. This project will implement an interdisciplinary curriculum that provides authentic research experiences for all STEM students in the College of Arts and Sciences at the University of New England. The investigators will create a project-oriented learning experience using the local estuary of the Saco River by developing new course modules, stimulating undergraduate research projects, conducting an interdisciplinary conference focusing on the project's theme, and implementing targeted faculty development. The investigators will examine the extent to which the increased hands-on, interdisciplinary approaches to student learning lead to increased student retention and persistence in STEM.

Across all STEM departments in the college, at least 29 courses with an enrollment of more than 1,600 students will work simultaneously on assessing, monitoring, or modeling aspects of the Saco River estuary. Students will investigate urban, salt marsh, intertidal, and open water habitats and apply methods of ecology, physiology, molecular biology, botany, zoology, mathematics, chemistry, and physics. A central database and web portal will make the data available for interdisciplinary data mining within the university and by the public. The investigators aim to demonstrate that experiential learning based on Kolb's learning theory can deepen students' understanding of the process of research as practiced by scientists in a long-standing NSF program, Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER). The activities will include working in groups to solve problems, using large data sets, and participating in the creation and sharing of data. Such an approach will also help students to comprehend science as more than rote learning -- as something that can be questioned and produced by them. Furthermore, the project will use place-based education to draw students into the project and into STEM. With this approach, (1) surrounding phenomena are the foundation for curriculum development, (2) students become creators rather than consumers of knowledge, (3) students' questions are central in determining what is studied, (4) teachers act as experienced guides and co-learners, and (5) the wall between school and community becomes permeable and is crossed frequently. Through repeated exposure to place-based education over their four years at the university, undergraduates will gain progressive, in-depth experiences with STEM, which will enable them to connect the process of discovery with learning and knowledge creation and will prepare them to be leaders, teachers, and innovators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project TURBO (The Undergraduate Saco River Biodiversity Observatory) implemented hands-on and research project-oriented learning experiences for undergraduates in multiple majors and departments across the whole college with the goal to increase retention rates in STEM. We leveraged our location at the Saco River estuary and designed multi-year research projects, carried out by students in many different classes at levels from freshman to senior year. In that way, students do their lab experiments in the context of an ongoing research project, they can use and build on an existing data set, feel that their work in the respective teaching activities actually matters, and see a connection of their teaching lab activities to real world applications. This leads to more motivation, a deeper understanding of the material, and ultimately, to increased retention in STEM. Implemented teaching modules include a succession study in marine fouling communities, studying biodiversity over seasons and time in the salt marsh and in woodland vernal pools, monthly assessments of invasive species in the intertidal zone, pH monitoring in river water, creating a database of hundreds of DNA barcodes of local marine and terrestrial invertebrate species, and more. Data from these teaching modules were used in the respective classes, in statistics courses to learn statistics on student-generated data, and in other classes that don’t do TURBO modules, but highlight student-generated data.

Over the 5 years of the grant STEM retention in the majors Biology, Marine Sciences, Chemistry, Physics, and Environmental Sciences increased from 74.6% to 91.2%. We can not claim that this increase in retention is solely due to Project TURBO, as the University has implemented a broad range of retention boosting initiatives within this 5-year period. Furthermore, we realized through our assessment efforts that many students were not as aware of Project TURBO as we intended to. However, we did see a large impact on the faculty who intentionally started using this different pedagogical approach as part of project TURBO, and independent of TURBO. Many faculty started to redesign teaching labs to incorporate more place-based, hands-on, and research-style activities. This probably explains the lack of visibility of TURBO to the students: faculty did not change their way of teaching due to TURBO per se, but because they realized the power of this teaching approach, and therefore did not broadcast Project TURBO as much. Consequently, we see a general culture shift in how our faculty teach. This is probably more than we could have hoped for, as this guarantees that the impact of project TURBO is long-lasting and will continue well past the funding period of this grant and will continue to lead to increased retention rates in STEM for a long time.
